> Hello, > > I'm new here. Then, welcome! ![:ph34r:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/scared9.gif) > After a long search and rescue trip on the internet i came along bootland. The info here is overwhelming and I'm missing the wood for the trees (for the moment). Don't worry, that happens to a lot of people, when they first try to deal with this kind of things. > I was trying to make a bootable USB to boot the SRD from BESR 2010. Do not assume that all the world knows knows the meaning of ALL acronyms and of ALL the products of ALL the software houses of the world ![:thumbup:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/thumbup.gif). SRD= System Recovery Disk BESR 2010=(Symantec's) Backup Exec System Recovery 2010 > Following Symantec's guidelines the USB does not want boot! WHICH ![:D](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/biggrin.png) guidelines? WHERE they can be found? (link please) "the USB does not want to boot" is NOT a description of what happens (it is the final result). We need some description of what happens, like: * a completely blank screen * a flashing cursor on top left of the screen (or a "j") * an error message (white characters on a black background) and EXACTLY which error it is * an error message (white characters on a blue background) and EXACTLY which error it is * nothing * something else .....

> What is going on and what do I need to make this happen? Generally speaking there are mainly two kinds of "cannot boot", one connected to the early phase of booting ("real mode"): * MBR, partition table, bootsector/PBR, bootloader, etc. and one to the "second phase of the booting ("protected mode") * drivers, actual OS setttings, etc. We need first thing (based on your description of what happens EXACTLY) to find out which of the two is the problem.
> P.S. Using Kingston 2GB DataTraveler USB stick. We need more details like: HOW it was partitioned/formatted. (WHICH app was used, with which settings, which filesystem used, etc. ) Please compare with: [http://homepages.tes...ard-litany.html](http://homepages.tesco.net/J.deBoynePollard/FGA/problem-report-standard-litany.html "External link") ![:dubbio:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/dubbio.gif) Wonko

forumNotes.author: ksanderash
forumNotes.content:
Aha, BOOTMGR -- that's the marker ![:dubbio:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/dubbio.gif)  

Download [Bootice](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=8986&hl=Bootice "External link") first of all.  

Then *Perform Format \> USB-HDD mode Single Partition \> Next \> FAT32 \> OK \> OK \> OK* .  
Then *Process MBR \> Windows NT 6.x MBR \> Install.*   
Then *Process PBR \> BOOTMGR boot record \> Install* .  

Now throw your files in UFD root. Done.  

This mini-guide should work for any WinPE 2.0-3.0 bootable environment (Windows 7 install too)

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
Hi It is fairly common (not normal) for some BIOSes to 'forget' the boot order once you switch on the system with the previously detected USB pen attached.
It works like this: 1. Switch on - BIOS detects USB pen model AAA is attached 2. User goes into BIOS and sets USB pen AAA as first boot device 3. Restart - system boots to AAA 4. Switch off, switch on - BIOS still boots to pen AAA 5. Switch off - remove USB pen - Switch on - Pen AAA no longer present so BIOS removes USB pen from boot list until you manually put it back in.
Some BIOSes 'forget' the USB pen as soon as you switch off the system. Also, if you change pen AAA to pen BBB, the BIOS boot order will also be 'forgotten'. Not sure why BIOS writers think this is a desirable function? I quite frequently find this behaviour and I have to ask the mainboard vendor to modify the BIOS, as our factory boots newly built systems from USB pen and we do not want to have to manually enter the BIOS to set the boot order each time!

S
